div.l: Tyll he were nyȝe oute of his prentyshode
All were he snybbed erly and late
And som̄tyme ledde with Revel to newgate
But at the laste his mayster hym bythouȝte
Vpon a day when̄ he his paper sought
Of a prouerbe that seith this same worde
Well bett̉er ys Roten̄ appull oute of a horde
Than̄ it Rote all the Remenᵃaunte
So fareth hit by a Ryotous ʆseruᵃaunte
Hit ys lesse harme to let hym passe
Than̄ he schende all the ʆseruuntꝭes in the plase
Therfor͗e his mayst̉er yaf hym aquytaunce
And bad hym go with sorow and myschaunce
And thus this Ioly prentys had his leve ·
Now lette hym Ryotte all the nyght or leve
And for ther is no thef with oute a loke
That helpeth hym to wasten̄ and sowke
Of þat he brybe kan̄ or borow may
Anon̄e he sente his bedde and his aray
Vn to a comper of his own̄ sorte
That loued dyse Revel and dysporte
And had a wyf that held for countenᵃauns
A schop̄ and swyued for hur sustynᵃauns
But her of woll y passe as now
And of Gamelyn̄ y woll tell yow ·
The Cokꝭes Tale
Lithen and lysten and herken aryght
And ye schull her͗e of a doughty knyght
Sir Iohn of boundys was his name
He cowde of norture and mychel game
Thre sonnꝭes he had and with his body hem wan
The eldest was a mych schrewe and sone he bygan
His bredern loued wel her fader and of hy wer͗e a gast
